Australia's environment is vast, isolated, diverse and rich in resources. Would it not be nice if we could actually use it to its full potential without constantly having impediments put in its place? It is a unique country to have such a wide range of assets. However, here we have further legislation which puts this country's diversity immediately at odds with any concept of national uniformity which presupposes that Australia and its population is one homogeneous mass. The council is therefore fundamentally flawed.

In remote areas of Western Australia which generate much of the nation's great wealth of mineral resources, which unfortunately the minor parties would have us cease forthwith, environmental issues are generally site specific and sustainable development requires localised criteria and management. The quality of Australian skills in this area is world renowned and what makes it so is its application to a diversity of global environments.

The state and territory governments have taken a particularly responsible attitude to the environment and are continuing to do so. They want the federal government to butt out. I believe it should butt out. It will be an unnecessary burden on all taxpayers. It is probably the most far reaching proposal ever made in this country and will continually override the interests of the states and the territories.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Environment Protection Council Bill 1994 is almost a misnomer as it would appear that the council created by this piece of legislation would be able to do little to protect the environment. The Greens (WA) would welcome a positive, nationally coordinated move to set enforceable standards for water, air and soil quality. We would welcome strong standards for permissible noise pollution, the disposal of hazardous waste, vehicle emissions and the re-use and recycling of materials.

PARA.TAB: This bill seeks to establish an authority which will be responsible for the publication, dissemination, monitoring and reporting on the implementation and effectiveness of national environment protection measures. These national environment protection measures cover such areas as ambient air and water quality, site contamination, environmental impacts of hazardous wastes and motor vehicle emissions. However, this bill does not set those standards. Instead it creates a process of consultation—something which the Greens (WA) usually support.

However, one has to question consultation when it is actually counterproductive to the aims set out. In this legislation the consultation process will at best be a long and drawn out one and at worst, as a first case example, will be easily derailed by an intransigent and spoiling state government such as the Court Liberal government in Western Australia. The Western Australian government has already indicated that it does not intend to participate in the National Environment Protection Council. I quote the Western Australian Minister for the Environment, Mr Kevin Minson, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no evidence that the National Environment Protection Council will improve environmental protection, environmental management or sustainable development in Australia.
I am forced to agree with my own state government's sentiments on this point, even if for very different reasons.

PARA.TAB: Because of the historical context from which this bill arises, it does not contain any sanction for a state which fails to participate. Just to refresh our memories, one of the biggest concerns about the intergovernmental agreements on the environment was that the Commonwealth gave away its overriding power to the states, and this legislation makes similar arrangements. There is no compulsion on the states to enact legislation or put in place arrangements to implement measures. The bill does not even contain any sanction for states which refuse to participate. Therefore, it will be marred by obfuscation from any state which does not want to agree to a national measure.

The states can use clause 15 of the bill in many different ways to foil environment protection. It requires the National Environment Protection Council to take into account cost effectiveness, and social and economic impacts as well as other existing international treaties or intergovernment mechanisms when developing a national environment protection measure. When important environmental considerations are to be weighed up against short-term social and economic impacts, then those environmental considerations will inevitably lose out. There is no sense of the precautionary principle being applied here.

If a state can argue that it is not regionally viable on economic grounds to put in place a particular environmental measure, the National Environment Protection Council will be compelled to accept this or see the state threaten to leave the process. There will be no penalty for leaving, let alone any penalty for agreeing and then failing to put in place complementary measures at a state level.

Although the sound of an intergovernmental agreement may be notionally a rational and practical solution to the limitations of particular governments in particular subject areas, it suffers from a basic lack of enforceability and accountability and can only effectively give us statements of government policy. My understanding is that there is no power and that, even if it was taken to the High Court on particular issues, there would be no possibility for any kind of judicial determination on the rights in the particular case. Furthermore, even if it could be taken to a higher authority or to a court, that court itself would encounter enforcement difficulties.

Basically, the federal government legitimately already has these powers because of its capacity to sign international treaties and to agree to universal standards of best practice. It already has funding power and the capacity to help states bring about better standards in the environment but it is virtually giving away those legitimate aspects of power. The legislation prevents the federal government and the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) from taking a direct role in setting clear standards on the environment and helping with the enforcement and implementation of those standards through legislative and funding support. This bill basically represents a washing of the hands of the federal minister for the environment and giving up his job to the states which have already demonstrated a very inferior capacity to look after those particular areas of concern.

In listening to Senator Knowles I was forced to agree with her concern that local community people who are desperately concerned about environmental conditions will see this bill as intrusive. She confused the terms local and state in her own mind. However, there are certainly three—and probably far more—different areas of deep concern about environmental issues.

One is the local community level, and people there in general are far more concerned about the environment than people at the federal government level have shown themselves to be. However, the point, particularly in my own state of Western Australia, is that often local communities find the federal government far more receptive than the state government to their concerns on environmental matters.

In my recent trip around the south-west of Western Australia and in the wheat belt the continual complaint was that the state minister for the environment was failing to protect the environment, was failing to do the job that the community wanted done, and that the only recourse for them was to appeal to the federal minister to intervene and try to persuade the state government to do its job. That arose in many instances, and it is an indication of international treaties giving local communities more power. It gives them a right of appeal beyond a state government that is being intransigent and refusing to listen to their concerns.

That is why the Greens are very unwilling to support a bill of this kind, because what it effectively does is try to tie down the standards of the federal minister for the environment to potentially lower standards that the states will be able to discuss. Not only that, but within the council even progressive states will be held back by those states that have different priorities for the measures that they want introduced.

This bill, as Senator Coulter said, really serves as an excuse for the federal minister for the environment not to exercise his legitimate powers; and the environment will be the loser. The public good is at stake with this legislation. This bill may well be good for maintaining—though I even doubt that—good state and federal relations, but it will do nothing to protect the environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the National Environment Protection Council Bill. I want to put on record a few concerns that I have with regard to this legislation and its potential impact. I believe that in dealing with people's environmental concerns this is a step backward, not a step forward. I say that for a number of reasons, the first being that it puts another level of bureaucracy in dealing with the various aspects of the necessary environmental controls and disciplines that are required. It is an expensive exercise, in my view. I also believe that it is toe in the door legislation. It is just the beginning of the intent of the government, although I do take note of the proposed amendment which means that in a short period the council could cease to exist.

PARA.TAB: It is duplication in the sense that we already have ANZECC, the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, which is dealing with a number of environmental matters. Its target is to give consistency, not uniformity. I endorse the comments of my colleague Senator Knowles. She made reference to the fact that it is not practical to try to entertain uniformity for environmental disciplines across Australia. As we all know, or we should know, there are enormous differences in what is required in various areas.I think this is the first step by the Commonwealth to remove from the states, and even from the administration of local governments and local people, their role in working out, with the right expertise, the way in which we should and need to travel with regard to conservation.

I wish to talk about my state of Western Australia. We already have in place very significant controls and disciplines for the necessary environmental requirements when any project might be going forward. We already have in place a number of controls for managing the national estate, whether it be in the forest, on public lands or even on crown land, which set out what people can and cannot do. They are very stringent and strong controls. We have only to go through the processes, which I will not detail now, to know what rehabilitation processes a mining company has to commit itself to before it can development a mining site. I believe that this legislation will create more problems. I think we could probably see in some instances this type of approach—what I call the minimal approach—becoming the standard.

I wanted to place on the record my concerns about certain aspects of this legislation. Hopefully, in time it will not come back to haunt us by, firstly, interfering with the proper processes of having proper environmental controls at a local level; and, secondly, interfering with the necessary requirements for having a balanced approach between development and the environment for sustainable development.

It is worth noting that in Western Australia we already have an environmental protection authority which is very rigid in the application of what it does. It is also in the process of doing a number of things which rely on people's goodwill and volunteering to be involved. I will give one example of that. It is currently looking at wetlands on private land in Western Australia, and people are going into what is known as a category A to manage those wetlands in a certain way to preserve them.

I have a little knowledge of this because I have some wetlands on my own property—a 100-acre lake. I have voluntarily agreed to put that lake under those particular controls. A lot of this work is going on. I believe that out of the government's approach we will see people becoming very concerned and hesitant to participate. It is one thing to deal with bureaucracy in one's own state; it is a totally different aspect to deal with it from Canberra. It will create an enormous amount of suspicion and concern and it will stop or interfere greatly with that cooperative approach which already exists.

I have already mentioned the situation of ANZECC, and I want to know what this new council is going to do that is not already being done. I want to know what function the council can carry out for the coordination between the states in addressing particular problems, and dealing with New Zealand at the same time and developing a regional approach. My view is that there is nothing it can do that is not already being done. I also want to point out the role that the conservation and land management department has in Western Australia in dealing with certain environmental aspects, and also the division of resource management which is dealing with the landcare situation in Western Australia.

I was fortunate last week—once again, I might add, but this time with the shadow minister for the environment, Ian McLachlan—to do a tour of Western Australia. It was very encouraging, particularly when we saw from the air some of the reclamation work that was being done in some of the catchment areas. I am the first to admit and acknowledge that there is a long way to go. However, we saw that problems have been identified and are being addressed—and successfully addressed. We also spent some time in the south-west looking at the development of plantation forests on both private and degraded public land.

I recommend to anybody who happens to be lucky enough to come to Western Australia to take the time to look at some of the work, and they will see that these problems are being addressed. There is only one reason why they are being addressed in a successful manner, and that is that the work is being done by local people on the ground who live there. As soon as we start putting in place such things as what is here beyond the ANZECC position, increasing that bureaucracy, we are going to create another level of suspicion around this whole process.

I have great reservations about this legislation. I do not believe that it will achieve what we are being told it will achieve. I also want to place on the public record some information I received from the Western Australian state minister, Kevin Minson. It seems that since 1990 there has been a change of position by the federal government, moving away from uniformity and towards consistency. While that, in itself, is a good thing, it does not mean there is still a necessity for this measure. We need to know what the government's long-term intention is. I will quote from the press statement put out yesterday by Mr Minson:

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted that in a recent letter to me which he circulated, Senator Faulkner now says that it would not be sensible or practical to require identical environmental protection measures in all parts of the country.

Senator Faulkner must now also admit that there is no need to create his new El Supremo of pollution control, the proposed National Environment Protection Council (NEPC). It would be unnecessary, costly, inefficient and a whole new layer of government bureaucracy.

He wants harmonious measures instead of uniform ones. I agree with such an aim, achieved through existing federal processes such as the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council.
I have already mentioned the council. The press statement continues:
ANZECC, without NEPC, is already far advanced on a National Water Quality Management Strategy.
The original justification of NEPC given by the Commonwealth Government was that it was the only way to achieve uniform national standards and override State and Territory pollution control agencies.

Expertise and responsibility rest with the States. Senator Faulkner now also agrees that measures may vary across a State. It makes no practical sense to try to centralise control and make each State Environmental Protection Authority an agent of the EPA in Canberra or NEPC.

I think it is important that these concerns that have been expressed by a number of people on this side of the chamber are put on the record. It is also important that we get a commitment from the government in terms of this legislation that the bureaucratic process is not going to interfere with a lot of good work that is already being done across Australia—whether it has to do with protection of the environment, identifying some areas as pristine and to be left alone, or whether it has to do with sustainable development. My concern is that every time we put a costly level of bureaucracy into the process, we end up with a result that is not the right result and which impacts in the wrong way.

PARA.TAB: Having raised those particular issues and concerns, I also note the amendment that Senator Ian Macdonald will move in due course. I particularly support this amendment because it will make this legislation much more sensible and it also emphasises the points that need to be made with regard to the amendments to be moved by the government. I suggest that those amendments have resulted from Senator Faulkner's somewhat changed position to that of the government's back in 1990 when the agreement was signed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak for long in summing up the second reading debate on the National Environment Protection Council Bill. I thank Senator Crane and other speakers for cooperating and not speaking at undue length on this legislation. The basic approach of the opposition, I have to say, was largely uninformed. I think we can best summarise its position as that of not having read the bill.
—Don't be so supercilious. You didn't even listen to the debate.

—How does Senator Macdonald know whether I was listening to the debate? I have been sitting here for the last hour listening to the debate, and it was a pretty tedious contribution that we heard from the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus, who has responsibility for the legislation, will be rebutting during the committee stage the contributions made by the opposition. The government is not prone to wasting time in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well sit down, then.

—That is exactly what I intend to do in a moment. I will not be repetitive in terms of some of the spurious contributions we heard from those opposite during the second reading debate. Senator Bolkus will deal very adequately with the specific and absurd complaints and some of the debating points that the opposition raised.

PARA.TAB: This legislation seeks to establish the National Environment Protection Council. This council will consist of a nominated minister from each participating jurisdiction. There has been very widespread consultation with the respective state governments on this matter. Is it not interesting that when we go to the states and try to develop a common position, we have so-called representatives of the states in this place—Senator Crane amongst them—whingeing about what is agreed? We attempt cooperative federalism; we attempt to have discussions in an amicable way; then we have the representatives of some of the states in this place complaining about the agreements that are reached. It is a great pity.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is reasonable.

—It is not reasonable when great efforts are gone to to reach accommodations. It is a federal system that we live in. Senator Crane should not complain, as he usually does, that the federal government has to override the states in some areas of jurisdiction. Senator Faulkner, one of our most impressive new ministers—
—Why has he backed away?
—He has not backed away. Again, it is the spirit of cooperative federalism and the spirit of a minister who recognises a substantial argument, who is willing to listen.
—Indeed; I acknowledged that and pointed it out to you. You didn't know about it.

—Yes, I did know about it. Senator Faulkner is a minister who listens. In his new portfolio responsibilities, on the couple of occasions on which I have had dealings with him on environmental issues, I would have to say that he is a minister who listens. That concludes my remarks on the process. I think it is important to note that a decision of the council that is being established must be supported by the votes of at least two-thirds of its members. We have had complaints from the opposition about a two-thirds vote.
—Don't be silly. We supported that. Read my speech.

—Senator Macdonald is silly. We heard his speech but his colleagues are still critical of this two-thirds vote. With regard to Senator Crane, everything has to come back to the lowest common denominator—Western Australia. That is his approach on some of these issues.
—Let me tell you that Senator Crane never mentioned the two-thirds vote.

—I am referring to Senator Crane's general approach on the right of veto for the Western Australian government. Almost every matter on which he has made a contribution in the Senate has come back to this lowest common denominator—Western Australia must have the right of veto. We have heard it in so many of his contributions in this place.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to talk for any longer on this matter. Senator Bolkus will take up, with his usual gusto and policy analysis, the particular issues that have been raised and which will be raised during the committee stage. I thank other speakers for their level of cooperation in ensuring a reasonably quick debate and hope that the legislation receives the speedy consideration that it deserves.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—While it is usual to deal with the preamble after the committee has dealt with the clauses of the bill, I suggest that the committee consider the preamble first because there are proposed amendments to the clauses which depend upon the proposed amendments to the preamble. We could then proceed according to the list of circulated amendments. Does that suit the wish of the committee? If it suits the wish of the committee, it is so ordered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill.
—The question is that the preamble stand as printed.

—Mr Chairman, the changes that we want to make to the preamble, as you have already indicated, anticipate further changes that we would make to the bill and, because this bill has this preamble if the amendments subsequently are accepted, the preamble clearly has to be changed, so it is a bit difficult. It is a chicken and egg situation, as you pointed out. Perhaps if I deal with some of the arguments in relation to the preamble, and if that is acceptable, then clearly certain amendments will flow from that. If it is not acceptable, then the amendments, presumably, would not be accepted either.
—Are you suggesting, Senator Coulter, that it might be best to take the amendments first and do the preamble last in the way that we normally do?

—No. I do not mind, except that the preamble is dealing with and is anticipating amendments in a number of different areas. That is the problem. So if part of our changes to the preamble are accepted, then that does create a difficulty. If, on the other hand, as I suspect, the government is not going to accept any of the changes in the preamble, then it clearly deals with all of our amendments as well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I can probably help you with that and make it clear at the start that we are not going to accept any parts of Senator Coulter's amendment to the preamble. That might clarify how we should go ahead. I suggest that we just go sequentially, start with the preamble first, and I think at the end of the day the end result will be the same.

—That certainly clarifies the position, and I think it amplifies a point which I made during the second reading debate—and the minister has not stated it here, but he may well state it for the record—and that is that this, again, is one of these pieces of legislation that comes out of intergovernmental agreements because it requires complementary legislation in other states in this case. We are prevented in this chamber from amending it and that, of course, bypasses the proper political process. We are elected into this chamber to consider this legislation on its merits and, if we seek to amend it, we should be permitted to amend it.

PARA.TAB: In this case—as I suspect, although the minister has not stated as such—one of the prime reasons that the government will not accept amendments is that we are dealing with this need for complementary legislation. I put this back to the opposition to consider the fact that it is wanting this complementary legislation. One downside of that is that that complementarity necessarily bypasses the proper political process: we cannot amend this legislation. We have been in that position before. Members of the opposition are picking this up quite frequently in relation to international agreements and saying that that is imposing requirements on Australia which are unacceptable and which bypass the proper political process and consideration, and, to a degree, we agree with them. I simply ask them to reflect on the fact that we are dealing with legislation which they want in this form because they want state involvement and yet the same principle is involved.

This preamble seeks to anticipate amendments in three areas. Firstly, it seeks to remove the references to take into account regional, environmental differences in Australia. We are taking a position here that is very different from that of the opposition. The intergovernmental agreement, which is published as a schedule to this bill, mentions for instance that among other things the parties agree that a national approach should be taken to rare, vulnerable and endangered species. This is given the fact that the distribution of these species and their habitats is not confined or determined by state or Commonwealth borders and that a national approach is desirable to avoid duplication of effort—the very thing that Senator Knowles was concerned about—to ensure appropriate outcomes and to maximise the effectiveness of available resources.

The various states and the Commonwealth recognised in this intergovernmental agreement the uniform nature of the problems in relation to terrestrial and aquatic species, degradation of land, salinisation and all those sorts of things, and the states have agreed to this need for uniform standards and legislation. So the provision in this bill for the recognition of regional environmental differences, we believe—and the opposition's amendment that it would seek to move later on goes even further—is simply a cop out, a way in which the environmental standards can be distorted to allow damaging processes to occur in one area or state and to give a state a temporary industrial, environmental advantage with lower costs to attract industry to that area, rather than to go into another area where higher standards obtain.

Incidentally, Senator Knowles cannot maintain that the states are doing a perfect job of looking after the environment when we have incredible land degradation and salinisation and the worst loss of species of any country in the world. We have feral animals that are raging across this country, across state borders. We have water quality which is deteriorating in every area. We have air quality in cities which is atrocious. We have greenhouse gas emissions, which are among the highest in the world. For Senator Knowles to somehow imply that the states are perfectly looking after the environment and there is no need for Commonwealth intervention just flies in the face of so much evidence. This first section of the preamble, which anticipates a later amendment to allow these regional differences, is simply to allow some parts of the country to get away with lower environmental standards and to continue to degrade their environment.

Secondly, we seek to provide for non-government environmental organisations to have observer status on the National Environment Protection Council. This goes part of the way to meeting that input by concerned, ordinary people that the opposition referred to so enthusiastically a few moments ago to allow their participation by way of having observer status on the National Environment Protection Council.

Indeed, contrary again to what Senator Knowles said and as I mentioned in my speech on the second reading debate, in the ANOP survey of 1991 when people right across Australia were asked whether they wanted and supported national environmental standards, 68 per cent said that yes, they supported national environmental standards. So they want the national standards but, of course, it is appropriate and there are mechanisms within this legislation by which they should have access to them.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade entitled Subsistence to supermarket: food and agricultural transformation in South-East Asia is interesting. It is a substantive work in terms of volume and has quite a lot of detail. Obviously, it has not been possible for me to read the 370-odd pages in the time that the document has been available to us. I focus, however, on some comments made in the document in relation to Vietnam. Whilst the document is generally fairly accurate, from what I can see, particularly in relation to its comment on Singapore and Brunei, I think it is appropriate to look at the comments that have been made about Vietnam, especially in view of the current interest in this country about liberalisation in Vietnam and some of the hype that has been going around.

PARA.TAB: On page 179 there is a prediction that the government will be unlikely to increase the scope of sugar production. I think the exact phrase is that the scope of further expansion of sugar cane production would appear limited and mainly focused on domestic demand. This comment is inaccurate. It is true that in previous years production of sugar has never exceeded 475,000 tonnes of raw sugar equivalent; last year it was about 420,000 tonnes.

But it is also very clear that the government has set as one of its priorities an increase in the production of raw sugar to one million tonnes per annum by the year 2000. It is not correct to say that there is limited scope for expansion of the sugar industry. In fact, the government is setting aside areas and is expected in the next year or two to open up an entirely new area for the production of sugar cane. The problems which have existed to date have been problems in relation to the processing of cane.

It is entirely possible that they could get substantially greater volumes of cane in Vietnam than are currently being grown at the moment. Remember that in Vietnam every single tonne of cane is cut by hand; most cane is grown on farms that do not exceed 1 1/2 hectares; and the cane is cut by the people who grow it. There is no effort at the moment to put mechanisation into the harvesting of cane and the varieties of cane that are grown are old and inefficient and the yields that are being achieved are very low.

As a consequence, there is substantial scope for improving the tonnage of cane which is cut, particularly with substantial investment from Taiwan. I know there is a proposal for the Taiwanese to build a sugar mill as well as plant between what I understand to be several hundred thousand tonnes of cane. There is very good scope for improvement in the tonnage of cane that will come off, and that will be driven very heavily by foreign investment. So I think it is a little dubious for us to assume that there will not be some growth in cane production.

I also note that the document overlooks one of the areas of growth for the Vietnamese agricultural industry, which is palm oil production, again driven on the back of investment from principally Malaysia this time. That is in reaction to a slow but noticeable increase in the cost of farm labour in Malaysia. Of course, palm oil production being reasonably labour intensive, the Malaysians have sought to move outside Malaysia and there has been very heavy investment in Vietnam.

I conclude my comments tonight by focusing on the comments about cattle production. It is true that cattle numbers have doubled to around 3.3 million head over the last decade. But that does not equate to good quality cattle or beef production. The average weight of an animal going to market, I understand from the national veterinary company, is only 200 on to 250 kilos live weight. The reason why the animals are so small at the age of three years is that they have been worked in the field pulling a plough for two or three years before finally being knocked on the head. As a consequence, they are animals of low carcass quality.

If we add to that the fact that there is rampant foot and mouth disease and tuberculosis, that there are no disease control mechanisms to prevent animals moving from infected areas to non-infected areas and that the farmers do not have the money to invest in looking after those animals, I think it is fair to say that the Vietnamese cattle industry does not offer a substantial threat to Australia.

There will be a big increase in the demand for meat coming into that area as a result of increasing standards of living. I think that is an area that we should, as a primary producer nation, be seeing as a big growth area for this country. At this point, unless somebody objects, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is a damning indictment of the government. It is, in fact, proof of the worst characteristic of this Labor Party and this Labor government. This is a high taxing, high spending, high deficit government and the proof is all here right in this document.

PARA.TAB: In 1993-94 this government spent $114 billion, up nearly $5 billion or 4.3 per cent. The government took in revenue of over $100 billion; for the first time in this nation's history, this government has taken from the Australian people in revenue over $100 billion. That was an increase of $5.6 billion, up 5.9 per cent, at a time when the recession was only just coming to an end. As a result, we have a deficit of $13.6 billion. So this is the national household spending $13.6 billion more than it received in income.

If we look in the document, we find hidden away in outlays is a credit of $2.4 billion for asset sales—this is selling the silver to pay the recurrent expenditure. So we have a real recurrent deficit of $16 billion. That is the underlying deficit run by this government—$16 billion. As a result, the government has had to borrow in the last financial year $13.6 billion, which has obvious consequences for real interest rates. We now have the highest real interest rates in the world. They have, of course, just gone up and they are going to keep on going up as a result of the deficit program of this government.

Public debt interest in 1993-94, as revealed in this document, was $6.5 billion; we had to pay out $6.5 billion just in interest. That is double the amount that South Australia lost on its state bank. We are paying that out in interest in just one year and, of course, we have deficits going on into the interminable future.

Total government spending under this government has nearly doubled in the last 10 years: it was $64 billion in 1984-85; it is now $114 billion. On the revenue side, revenue has gone up 5.9 per cent in the last financial year compared to an inflation rate of only 1.8 per cent. If we look at the crunch issue, total income tax on individuals, as revealed by this document, has gone up 4.7 per cent in real terms. At a time when we are just trying to come out of a recession and we have massive problems with unemployment, this government is taking from Australians another 4.7 per cent in real terms in personal taxation.

Sales tax went up 10.8 per cent in real terms in the last financial year. The hypocrisy of this government is unbelievable. This is the first financial year after the government's campaign against the GST, and it has increased sales tax by 10.8 per cent in real terms. Excise duty is up 10 per cent in real terms under a government that campaigned against the goods and services tax. Total tax revenue has almost doubled in 10 years of Labor. It has gone from $53 billion in 1984-85 to nearly $94 billion in 1993-94. Of course, when we add other revenue we get over $100 billion. It is an indictment of Labor and it is something that we will be reminding the electorate about from now right through to the election.

Under this government tax revenue in real terms has been increased in all but two of the last 10 financial years. In eight of the last 10 financial years, tax revenue—the money this government takes from ordinary Australians—has increased in real terms. Despite taking so much money out of the hands of ordinary Australians, the government still continues to run big deficits. We have to pay tax money to pay the interest on the debt, and the debt keeps accumulating every year. This document is a classic example of what is wrong with Labor and what distinguishes us from Labor. Labor is the party of high taxes, high spending and high deficits.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this day which should be recognised as a special day for men around Australia, I would like to raise an issue which is gaining recognition from a growing number of Australians. It is a matter which is of major health and welfare concern. It is a leadership problem and a problem which needs to be addressed as a matter of national priority.

PARA.TAB: Mr Steve Biddulph, a very successful Tasmanian author, has identified the problem and has suggested some solutions in his new book entitled Manhood—a book about setting men free. I intend to quote extensively from a review of the book published in the Sunday Tasmanian of 19 June and written by Matthew Denholm. I think that so doing will provide a more succinct overview of the argument being put forward by Steve Biddulph than I could do otherwise. The argument is simply, and I quote from the review, that:
While women had to overcome oppression, he argues—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, Steve Biddulph—
men have to overcome loneliness, compulsive competition with other men and "lifelong emotional timidity".

PARA.TAB: Men are not winners, he says, and few are happy.

He points out men live on average six years less than women, fail at relationships (four out of five divorces are initiated by women), carry out 90 per cent of violent crimes, make up 90 per cent of gaol inmates and are 74 per cent of the jobless.
Boys, he says, make up 90 per cent of children with behaviour problems and 80 per cent of children with learning difficulties.
"Suicide is the leading cause of death in males—one in every 32 Australian males dies at his own hands," he says. "That's five times the rate for women."
They judge themselves by their pay-packets, are ashamed of their sexual feelings and see other men as competitors.
The book sums it up: "Men are a mess—our marriages fail, our kids hate us, we die from stress and on the way we destroy the world."
It spends the next nine chapters setting out solutions but Biddulph says every man must take the first step and "admit you're stuffed".
And he is quick to stress his book and the men's movement in which he believes are not just a "male backlash".
"My aim in writing this book was to end the battle of the sexes—to bring an understanding of men and how to help them," he says.

SPEECH.PARA: The review states that Steve Biddulph says further:

PARA.TAB: "I'm not interested in pointless arguments about which gender has had the worst time."
Biddulph says the men's movement is the "women's movement's missing half" and "you can't liberate only half the human race".
His suggestion—

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that certain honourable senators would be very interested in this—
men burn their ties—or use them to tie tomato plants—is not entirely tongue-in-cheek.
He sees ties as a slave symbol and says that he thinks they will disappear. The review continues:

PARA.TAB: He puts it more strongly in the book: "A tie symbolises something very profound—a willingness to fit in, or even to submit . . .
But what are the big solutions to men's problems?
For a start, he says, men must sort out differences and coolness with their fathers, find sacredness in their sexuality and develop proper friendships with other men.

They must also "stand up to" their wives as equals in a non-violent way, spend more time with their kids, "find a job they believe in or something to believe in about their job", and discover a spiritual basis for their lives.
It is, as the book says, a "very simple map for very complex terrain".

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Steve Biddulph that this is a question of national importance. It is a question which should concern this parliament. Our leaders would do well to consider his thesis because Australia needs a humanising of their leaders. We need elders rather than street fighters.

(5) Has AHS been carrying out any research into noise-induced hearing; if so: (a) what has been the allocation within the AHS budget to carry out such research; (b) does that research cover workplace noise; (c) if the research carried out covers workplace noise, what is the nature of the research; (d) what policy or policies does AHS follow in relation to this research; and (e) is the AHS research program linked with its own prevention/education programs or those of other organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 June 1994:

(2) Has the Australian Mint been successful in commercial negotiations with any other foreign countries to sell the rights to this process and/or produce the notes in Australia.
(3) Has the United States' Government been approached with a proposal to consider using Australian technology in production of their banknotes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) One of the major advantages in polymer note technology is that it enables the incorporation of anti-counterfeiting devices not available with the traditional use of paper. The advantages of polymer notes are only available to a limited number of other countries that have had polymer notes printed by Note Printing Australia, a division of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

(2) To date, Note Printing Australia has printed polymer currency notes (in Australia) for Indonesia, Kuwait, Papua New Guinea, Singapore and Western Samoa. While the majority of these have been commemorative issues, polymer notes do circulate in Western Samoa and Papua New Guinea and, to a limited extent, in Singapore. Many other countries have expressed interest in the technology and Note Printing Australia maintains close contacts with potential purchasers.

(3) The Reserve Bank maintains a close and on-going relationship with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the US Bureau of Engraving and Printing, the issuer and printer respectively of US currency notes. Detailed discussions have taken place with these authorities on polymer note technology over many years. However, no formal requests have been received or proposals made for US currency note production.

(7) What is the cost of sending the magazine to its recipients.
(8) Who produces the magazine.
(9) Why did the Quay Connection evaluate the magazine in April 1994, when they were also paid $23 320 in April 1994, for the production of the magazine.
(10) What was the outcome of the evaluation of the Lingo magazine.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Lingo is a quarterly magazine aimed at the corporate sector which promotes the value to business of language skills and the understanding of other cultures. It contains practical advice to senior executives in the tourism, exporting and manufacturing industries and showcases products with a commercial orientation in the field of languages.
(2) The first edition of the magazine was launched in December 1992.

(3) Lingo is now in its second year of publication and it is timely to assess its impact on the target audience and hence gauge its effectiveness. The evaluation is being done by Reark Research Pty Ltd at a cost of $19 500.
(4) There were no other costs associated with the evaluation beyond this payment.
(5) Each edition costs $40,000. There have been six editions.

(6) The magazine is sent by direct mail to members of the House of Representatives and Senators; approximately 250 of Australia's leading businesses; employer associations and trade unions; State and Territory TAFE Ministers, TAFE colleges and Directors; higher education institutions, peak higher education organisations and interest groups, learned academies and student unions; State and Territory education authorities and school interest groups such as affiliates of the Australian Council of State School Organisations, the Australian Parents Council, the National Council of Independent Schools, the Australian Early Childhood Association, teacher unions and principals' associations; to all Branches in DEET and to the heads of Commonwealth Departments and Agencies; large libraries; the media; all Embassies and High Commissions in Australia; and interest groups focussed on training, disability, youth, Aboriginal, religious, rural, and women's issues. It is also distributed by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Asia in Australia Council to the business community.
(7) Quay Connection's distribution costs for the four editions of the magazine published between 31 March 1993 and 31 March 1994 were $5 661.91.
(8) Lingo is produced by the Quay Connection, 10 Quay Street, Sydney.

(9) In April 1994, Quay Connection was paid a balance of $23 320 (on top of the $16 680 it was holding) to complete the production of the sixth issue of Lingo. Due to production schedule delays, this sixth issue of Lingo, which was scheduled to be published in March 1994, was not published until April 1994.

As mentioned in the response to part 3 of this question, with Lingo in its second year of publication, the Department decided to assess the impact the magazine was having, before making a decision on the funding of further editions. Consistent with normal practice in the case of the evaluation of projects in which Departmental officers are not closely involved, the Department asked the project managers, Quay Connection in this instance, to commission an evaluation, on the usual basis that DEET would vet the preferred proposal and be involved in the steering committee.

Quay Connection obtained three expressions of interest and recommended the Reark Research Pty Ltd proposal. The recommendation was accepted and Quay Connection was granted $19 500 to commission the evaluation.
(10) A draft final report on the evaluation is due in the near future.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale and Purchase of Dangerous Goods

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 23 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an advertisement placed in a national magazine by Wellington Surplus Stores, Perth, advertising various equipment, including replica plastic pistols, incapacitating spray packs, hand-cuffs and police truncheons:
(1) What are the requirements of Federal, State and Territory legislation covering the sale and purchase of the above products.
(2) Is the firm liable for prosecution in selling items to customers in a state which prohibits the possession of such items.
(3) Is the customer ordering such items liable for prosecution.
(4) Is the magazine publisher liable for prosecution in publishing the advertisement in states in which the products are banned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: There are at present no Federal controls on replica plastic pistols, incapacitating spray packs, hand-cuffs or police truncheons. The Trade Practices Act 1974 and equivalent State/Territory consumer protection laws, however, have in the past been used to prohibit the supply of goods which are dangerous to consumers. In relation to State and Territory provisions, legislation differs between jurisdictions and the honourable senator should pursue this matter with individual jurisdictions.

The Commonwealth is, however, strongly committed to curbing the availability of dangerous goods in the community and has played a leading role in having this issue addressed by the Australasian Police Ministers' Council. In May 1994, Ministers agreed to the expansion of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations to include pistol crossbows, nunchukus, blowpipes, blowpipe darts and ballistic knives. Ministers also agreed to work towards the development of national standards on the prohibition of dangerous goods to ensure greater uniformity and cooperation between jurisdictions.

In relation to Parts 2 and 3 of the honourable senator's question, these are matters for individual States and Territories, until such time as there are national standards on the prohibition of dangerous goods.
In relation to the liability of the magazine publisher, this is entirely dependent on the particular State and Territory legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: Please provide, on an electorate basis, Australia wide:
